https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9emRkxZ.auction_subtitle: 1 Owner, Extensive Modifications, Engine Rebuilt in 2020, 5-Speed Manual
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9emRkxZ.dougs_take: If you're looking for a one-of-a-kind Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution, you've just found it. This is a one-owner car that features a LONG list of modifications (one of the longest I've ever seen on Cars & Bids!) intended to improve performance, handling, and style – there's not a lot left on this car that still carries a Mitsubishi part number, and the result is an output of 472 horsepower at the wheels, which is a major increase over the stock figure. This Evo also boasts a 5-speed manual transmission, and it benefits from a documented engine overhaul performed at about 58,600 miles – this should give bidders a tremendous amount of peace of mind. It looks like a lot of resources went into this build, and I'm sure the next owner will have a lot of fun with it.
auction_highlights: The attached Carfax history report shows that this is a one-owner car.

Highlights from the extensive list of modifications reported by the seller include Manley forged H-beam connecting rods, Wiseco forged pistons, a Garrett Motion GTX3582R turbocharger, an Extreme Turbo Systems 4-inch intercooler, Injector Dynamics 1,000-cc fuel injectors, an HKS Hi-Power exhaust system, a Clutch Masters Industries lightweight flywheel, 19-inch SSR Professor SP4 wheels, TEIN Super Street coilovers, a Victory Function wide-body kit, BRIDE GIAS-Series Low Max II front seats, and an Autopower Industries 4-point rear roll cage with harness and cross bars.
An invoice pictured in the gallery shows that the engine was rebuilt in October 2020 at 58,590 miles.

Mitsubishi's 10th and final Lancer Evolution arrived for 2008. It gained a new, more powerful engine, a revised suspension system, and a design inspired by sharks and fighter jets, according to the company. MR denoted an automatic transmission; stick-shifted variants were called GSR. Mitsubishi canceled the Lancer Evolution in 2016, and it all but confirmed the model will not return in the foreseeable future.

Power comes from a 2.0-liter turbocharged 4-cylinder engine, rated at 291 horsepower and 300 lb-ft of torque when left stock. The modifications increase those figures to about 472 and 360, respectively, at the wheels, according to a dyno sheet pictured in the gallery. The engine spins the four wheels via a 5-speed manual transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9l5n8jB.auction_subtitle: Honda B18C Engine Swap, 5-Speed Manual, Numerous Modifications
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9l5n8jB.dougs_take: Now THIS is special! The Fiat X1/9 was always a fun sports car, but this particular example is not your run-of-the-mill X1/9. It’s powered by a Honda B18C 4-cylinder engine, meaning it now has well over twice the horsepower it had when it left the factory – and probably some added reliability, too. This X1/9 also boasts a long list of supporting modifications, including a Honda 5-speed manual transmission, a limited-slip differential, seats from a Mazda MX-5, and more. This Fiat should be a proper hoot to drive, and I’m excited to see it on Cars & Bids!
auction_highlights: The attached Carfax history report starts in 1991 and contains several gaps, but shows no accidents for the given time period.

Modifications to this X1/9 are extensive, and the full list is detailed below. Highlights include a bored and sleeved Honda B18C engine swap, a Honda 5-speed manual transmission with a limited-slip differential, 14-inch Campagnolo wheels, a custom fabric targa top, and NC MX-5 Miata seats.

The Fiat X1/9 was introduced in 1972, and immediately caught the attention of enthusiasts with its striking styling, fun driving character, and affordable pricing. Penned by Bertone, the X1/9 came with a removable targa top that could be stored in the frunk, and while it didn’t offer the big power its wedge shape left you to believe, it quickly gained the “baby Ferrari” nickname due to its excitement when dealing with corners. When Fiat exited the U.S. market, Malcolm Bricklin set up International Automobile Importers and agreed with Bertone to continue production and sell the mid-engined X1/9 under the latter’s badges until 1988, when production was officially stopped.

Power comes from a modified Honda “B18C” 2.0-liter inline-4 engine, which according to the owner currently makes around 215 horsepower, but a dyno sheet was not provided to confirm. Output is sent to the rear wheels via a 5-speed manual transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/rJzjdPz.auction_subtitle: NO RESERVE Heavily Modified for Drag Racing, 6.7-Liter V8, Nitrous Injection System
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/rJzjdPz.dougs_take: Old-school Chevrolet models benefit from a HUGE amount of aftermarket support, and this Monte Carlo SS illustrates that point well. It has been extensively modified for drag racing – it features a 6.7-liter V8 (!), massive rear tires, a nitrous injection system, and an 8-point roll cage, among other aftermarket parts. The line lock is a great feature to have if you're planning on taking this car to the drag strip, and this Monte Carlo retains features such as lights and turn signals, so it should be street-legal in some states. It's also offered with the thrill of no reserve, so this should be an exciting auction to watch and participate in.
auction_highlights: This Monte Carlo's factory-fitted 5.0-liter V8 was replaced by a modified 6.7-liter (406-cubic-inch) V8, according to the seller. The list of modifications reported by the seller also includes Brodix cylinder heads, a 200-shot nitrous injection system, an aluminum radiator, a Triangle Engineering 7-gallon aluminum fuel cell, an MSD Digital 6-Plus ignition system, a removable 4-inch exhaust system, a Currie Enterprises 9-inch rear end, a line lock device, 15-inch Cragar wheels, an 8-point roll cage, Kirkey Racing Seats front seats with Simpson Race Products 5-point harnesses, and Autometer Products gauges.

Chevrolet's fourth-generation Monte Carlo made its debut for 1981 with a boxier design and a platform shared with models built by Buick and Oldsmobile. The range initially included V6 and V8 engines, and Chevrolet injected a dose of performance into the line-up by bringing back the SS for 1983. Production ended in 1988, and the nameplate laid dormant until the fifth-generation model arrived for 1995.
Power comes from a 6.7-liter V8. It spins the rear wheels via a 3-speed automatic transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/35PjJWg.auction_title: 1997 Subaru Legacy GT-B Twin Turbo Wagon
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/35PjJWg.auction_subtitle: NO RESERVE Rare Japanese-Market Wagon, 2.0L Twin-Turbo Flat-4, AWD, U.S. Title
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/35PjJWg.dougs_take: This is awesome! Although the North American market didn't get any really performance-focused versions of this Subaru Legacy, the Japanese market did – like this high-performance GT-B Twin Turbo. It boasts a 2.0-liter flat-4 that's twin-turbocharged to about 280 horsepower, which is a big number – and it touts a U.S. title for peace of mind. Other benefits include all-wheel drive and several desirable modifications including aftermarket coilovers and Enkei wheels. I also love the fact that this wagon's exterior design remains relatively subtle; only the most hardcore enthusiasts will know that it's approaching Golf R power – and no reserve makes this fast wagon even more appealing.
auction_highlights: This is a right-hand drive, Japanese-market wagon that's titled in Maryland. Reportedly imported in 2022, it's equipped with a metric instrument cluster and its odometer displays about 87,400 kilometers, which represents approximately 54,300 miles.

Modifications reported by the seller include aftermarket parts in the exhaust system, 17-inch Enkei T6R wheels, Godspeed Project Mono-RS coilovers, Subaru WRX PowerStop front and rear brake rotors, a Pioneer head unit, and a microphone for Bluetooth connectivity. Factory equipment includes fog lights, a roof rack, dual sunroofs, front sport seats, a MOMO steering wheel, and air conditioning.

In the United States, Subaru introduced the second-generation Legacy as a sedan and as a station wagon for the 1995 model year. Front-wheel drive came standard, and all-wheel drive was offered at an extra cost. Its main claim to fame is spawning the original Outback, which gave Subaru's American sales a considerable boost. Production ended in 1999, and Subaru never sold the GT-B model on our shores.
Power comes from a 2.0-liter twin-turbocharged flat-4, rated at about 280 horsepower and 250 lb-ft of torque. It spins the four wheels via a 4-speed automatic transmission.

The G's upmarket ascent started when the extensively updated W463 arrived in 1990. It looked a lot like the original G, but it gained a longer list of features and a permanent four-wheel-drive system. American sales officially started for the 2003 model year and civilian production ended in 2018. The convertible model, which was never imported to the United States by Mercedes-Benz, retired in 2014.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/3y0BNyo.dougs_take: The Mitsubishi Pajero (which we knew as the Montero) is an absolute icon in the rally world – and the Evolution model is the street-legal version of the SUV that won the 1998 Paris-Dakar Rally. The Pajero Evo is an underrated homologation special, and it's exceptionally rare – only about 2,500 units were built. This particular example is finished in silver, and it features some nice upgrades like 17-inch Black Rhino wheels, Ralliart mud flaps, a Recaro SP3 low mount driver's seat, a Lancer Evolution VIII MOMO steering wheel, and an aftermarket head unit with Apple CarPlay capabilities. auction_highlights: This is a right-hand drive, Japanese-market SUV that's registered in Vermont. It's equipped with a metric instrument cluster, and its odometer displays about 134,900 kilometers, which represents approximately 83,900 miles.

Factory equipment includes front and rear Torsen limited-slip differentials, a locking center differential, skid plates, an Evolution-specific body kit, a trailer hitch, Recaro front sport seats, an information display on the dashboard, and air conditioning, among others listed below.

Modifications reported by the seller include 17-inch Black Rhino wheels, auxiliary lights on front bumper, black Evolution badges, door window air deflectors, aftermarket side steps, auxiliary reverse light, Ralliart mud flaps, a Recaro SP3 low mount driver's seat, a Lancer Evolution VIII MOMO steering wheel, aftermarket door upholstery, Ralliart pedal covers, and an aftermarket head unit with Apple CarPlay capabilities.

Mitsubishi released the Pajero Evolution in 1997 to homologate the SUV in the Dakar Rally. Starting with the short-wheelbase model, the company added a full body kit characterized by wheel arch flares, an all-around independent suspension system, a quicker steering system, and a more powerful engine, among other rally-inspired changes. Its efforts paid off: the Pajero took first, second, third, and fourth in the 1998 Dakar. Most historians agree that approximately 2,500 street-legal Evolution models were built.

Power comes from a 3.5-liter V6, rated at about 276 horsepower and 257 lb-ft of torque. Called 6G74 internally, it spins the rear or the four wheels via a 5-speed automatic transmission and a 2-speed transfer case.

Unquestionably one of the most significant cars in Volkswagen's history, the original Golf arrived in America as the Rabbit for 1976 to replace the Beetle. Early models were imported from Germany though later cars were built in Pennsylvania, and sales in the United States ended in 1984, though the convertible variant remained in the Volkswagen range for another decade.

Volkswagen released the Rabbit Pickup for 1979 to compete against small Japanese pickups like the Chevrolet LUV. As its name implied, the model was closely related to the Rabbit hatchback under the sheet metal and fuel economy was highlighted as one of its main selling points. Production for the United States ended in 1984, but the Rabbit Pickup lived on abroad (where it was sometimes called Caddy) until the 2000s. As of 2022, it remains the first, last, and only mass-produced Golf-based pickup.
Power comes from a 1.6-liter diesel inline-4, rated at approximately 52 horsepower and 71 lb-ft of torque. Output is sent to the front wheels via a 4-speed manual transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9XA8QGk.auction_subtitle: Over $60,000 in Modifications, Dyno-Tuned to 757hp, 5-Speed Manual
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9XA8QGk.dougs_take: This is wild!! The Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution X was quick even when left stock, but this one features over $60,000 in modifications intended to improve performance and handling. It notably received a new engine in 2021, which is a major benefit, and it's equipped with an aftermarket turbo and stronger rear axles. It's also been dyno-tuned to 757 horsepower, which is over twice the factory output! The clean, accident-free Carfax report is a huge benefit (a lot of similar builds start with a salvaged car), and this Evo also touts the 5-speed manual transmission that enhances the driving experience. It looks like a lot of resources went into building this Evo, and I'm happy to see it on Cars & Bids.
auction_highlights: The attached Carfax history report lists no accidents in this sedan's past.

Invoices pictured in the gallery detail over $61,000 in repairs, maintenance, and modifications performed on this Lancer since February 2021. The list of modifications reported by the seller includes an AMS Performance Stage 2 crate engine, a TephraXMOD V3 tune, an Extreme Turbo Systems turbocharger kit, a Boostin Performance Double Pumper fuel system, Injector Dynamics ID2000 fuel injectors, a Boostin Performance H-pattern shifter, an EXEDY HD Hyper Twin clutch kit, a Magnus Motorsports clutch master cylinder, an Evolution VII-sourced rear differential, 18-inch Titan 7 wheels, Hawk Performance brake pads, Burple paint, APR Performance carbon fiber door mirrors, and Sparco Chrono Road front seats. Some of the removed factory parts and some spare parts (including an engine) are included in the sale.

Mitsubishi's 10th and final Lancer Evolution arrived for 2008. It gained a new, more powerful engine, a revised suspension system, and a design inspired by sharks and fighter jets, according to the company. MR denoted an automatic transmission; stick-shifted variants were called GSR. Mitsubishi canceled the Lancer Evolution in 2016, and it all but confirmed the model will not return in the foreseeable future.

Power comes from a 2.0-liter 4-cylinder engine, rated at 291 horsepower and 300 lb-ft of torque when left stock. The modifications increase those figures to 757 and 522, respectively, when the engine burns E85 fuel, according to a dyno sheet pictured in the gallery. The engine spins the four wheels via a 5-speed manual transmission.
